awd_titl_txt: CSEDI Collaborative Research: Understanding the nature of water transport between the transition zone and the lower mantle through the interdisciplinary studies
awd_abstract_narration:
Earth is the water planet, with much of its H2O chemically bound within its rocky interior. The goal of this project is to provide new insight into the way in which water circulates, carried by the slow heat convection of Earth's silicate mantle. Geophysicists now have strong evidence that there is a substantial amount of water in Earth's interior, perhaps more than the current mass of the oceans. There is strong evidence that most of this water resides within the mantle transition zone (MTZ), between 410 km and 660 km depth in the Earth. The MTZ spans the stability range of minerals that can incorporate water within their crystal structures, up to a mass-fraction of a percent or more.  It appears that the transition zone acts as a refillable reservoir of mineral-bound water within Earth's interior. The water in Earth's surface oceans can exchange with the water in the mantle transition zone via mantle convection, on time scales of 10-30 million years. How does the transition zone maintain its elevated water content as mantle rock flows upward and downward through it, converting to water-phobic minerals at its boundaries, particularly at its lower boundary at ~660-km depth?  The goal of this project is to study the MTZ and lower-mantle minerals at high pressure in the lab and with computer simulations to determine how the water behaves near 660-km depth, and to detect water expulsion from descending rock masses using scattered seismic waves.  The award will provide graduate and undergraduate training, including summer research projects, for several students in a broadly interdisciplinary research project.

Understanding the nature of large-scale water transport in Earth's deep interior is one of the key issues in the study of evolution of Earth (and other planets). Since diffusion is inefficient, the most important process to control the large-scale transport of water is melting and subsequent melt-solid separation. The goal of this study is to improve our understanding on these two issues. Melting likely occurs when water-rich materials in the transition zone are brought into upper or the lower mantle where the water solubility in minerals is low. However, when metallic iron is present, then a majority of water partitions into it. Hence metallic iron has a controlling effect on the melting behavior. One aspect of this research is to obtain a better understanding of metallic iron content in the lower mantle. When melt is formed, most of water (hydrogen) goes to the melt. Melt migrates up or down depending on its density relative to the unmelted residual rock. Melt density under deep-mantle conditions has not been constrained well, particularly considering the range of likely chemical compositions. This project will investigate melt density under deep-mantle conditions with different redox values and plausible variations in the iron-magnesium ratio. Combining these, the investigators will have an improved view of deep-Earth water circulation.  With scattered seismic waves, primarily using the receiver-function technique, the team will map out locations beneath the mantle transition zone where water-enhanced partial melt is present.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
It is now well recognized that the ocean mass on Earth is controlled by the dynamic balance of degassing (addition of water to the oceans from Earth's interior) and regassing (removal of water from the oceans to Earth's interior). Anything controlled by the dynamic balance can be unstable in many cases, and therefore geological inference of nearly constant sea level (~ nearly constant ocean mass) needs explanation. Since degassing by the shallow processes (melting below mid-ocean ridges) is inefficient in controlling the ocean mass, any model to explain this near constant ocean mass should focus on processes in Earth's deep interior. 

The purpose of this project is to make further progress in our understanding of how water is transported in the deep interior of Earth. Particularly important region we focus is the boundary between the "transition zone" and the "lower mantle" at around 700 km depth. Based on previous studies including our own (Karato, 2011), there is a consensus in the geological community that the transition zone (~400-660 km depth) is a region with high water content. The possible total water content in those region is substantially higher then the water content in other rocky regions of Earth. Therefore the ways in which water is circulation across the transition zone is a key to understand how water circulate in the whole Earth that controls the history of the ocean mass.

Key observations to get some insights into those processes include seismological observations of low velocity regions. When a large amount of water is transported to regions where minerals cannot dissolve much water, then (partial) melting will occur that can be detected by seismology as low velocity regions. Our project includes detailed seismological studies to detect these subtle features and we demonstrated anomalous regions across the mantle transition zone that may carry critical information on water circulation.

Also important are two mineral physics issues: (i) in the lower mantle, the solubility of water is generally low that promotes melting. However, there was laboratory studies showing that metallic Fe is formed in the lower mantle. Metallic Fe has large water (hydrogen) solubility, and therefore if there is enough metallic Fe, then melting will not occur. We conducted a laboratory study on metallic Fe formation, and found that the amount of metallic Fe decreases with pressure. Therefore, in the shallow lower mantle melting may be prevented by metallic Fe, but as one goes to a deeper region, the amount of metallic Fe decreases, and melting may start. This threshold depth is inferred to be 700-800 km.

(ii) Another mineral physics issue relevant to this project is the density contrast between the melt and the surrounding solid minerals. When melt is lighter than minerals, melt will migrate up. When melt is denser than minerals, melt will sink. Depending on the nature of density contrast, evolution of water content in the mantle will be entirely different. Our first-principle calculations show that in most of the shallow lower mantle (<1000 km depth), melt is lighter than the surrounding minerals even if melts contains water.

In combining the results from these individual studies, we propose a model of global water circulation including a model to explain the history of ocean mass as recorded by the sea level change. In this model, melting above and below the transition zone plays a key role, and because the water content in the transition zone is controlled by the melting relationship, the water content in the transition zone is regulated, and as a consequence, the ocean mass is also regulated. This model provides an explanation for why ocean mass has been stable in the geological history.
